misconceptions.inferred_category_name: In-place String mutation expectation (Strings are mutable)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes calling a String method like toUpperCase() or replace(...) will directly change the original String variable (or that Strings behave like mutable objects).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, String objects are immutable. Methods like toUpperCase() and replace(...) do not modify the existing String object; they create and return a new String. A variable only “changes” if you assign that returned String back to a variable. (In this particular submission, the student actually assigns the results correctly, so this misconception is not causing a bug—but it’s the key mental-model pitfall this question is trying to test.)
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error in this code; potential future error would be unchanged output if the student called methods without assignment (e.g., input.toUpperCase(); then printing input).
